author: undying1200
content: Do a search on this Discord alone and you will find a lot of POW developers asking questions about this new system we call POS. It is very naive to think we can just switch to a new base system like POS and all the devs will be able to implement sharding without learning a new system (POS) first.  The original concept made sense to introduce sharding first on POW before moving it into POS. Working in parallel would have been the best way to implement and then finally merge. This allows you to use the full 1.0 client dev teams to work on sharding in an environment they understand and are experts.

author: djrtwo
content:
> This is my guess why sharding is being pushed to the side as it is quite apparent small validators will be pushed out using sharding in POS
This is an incorrect guess

Eth2 attempts 3 things -- make the protocol more secure, sustainable, and scalable.
Sharding is being prioritized only after the merge because rollups coming online get much more *scale* out of ethereum in the next 3 to 6 months. Then, sharding (more L1 data) would enhance this scalability after.
Thus we can focus on the merge today to bring more security and sustainablility to the protocol today

author: djrtwo
content: in combination, rollups + the merge give us a good dose of the three goals whereas sharding will enhance scalability later
